properties.description: Scuba-diving the Great Barrier Reef.
One of the dozen of colorful fish.
On our way to Norman Reef we quickly stopped at the resort on Green Island.
Lunch at Laguna Chiar Kkota.
Árbol de Piedra.
Laguna Colorada.
Our jeep.
All Cordillera-travelers.
Professional underwater photograph.
Old steam clock striking nine o’clock.
The first Starbucks, dated 1912.
Public market selling mostly fish.
View from Seattle ’s Space Needle.
Seattle waterfront.
On the watertaxi.
Small Pioneer Square in the historic center of Seattle.
Old timers at The LeMay - America’s Car Museum.
One of our favorites.
Seattle’s underground resulted from a city-wide fire in 1889.
Tulip exposition in the Roozengaarde in the Skagit Valley.
View of Mt. Rainier on the way to Los Angeles.
The view from our room.
Getting settled in business class on our way to Sydney.
Typical breakfast with homemade jam, guacamole, pineapple, ham, and local cheese accompanied with a cup of coca tea.
At the Koala Park.
Kangaroos.
Koala’s sleep up to 20 hours a day, and when they’re awake they eat all the time.
Bondi Beach: a popular surf spot around 30 minutes outside of Sydney.
Sydney Opera House.
Harbor Bridge.
Circular Quay, the harbor of Sydney.
Sunset over the Opera House.
Magnificent views of the Blue Mountains.
Very similar to the Grand Canyon, except with trees.
Wentworth Falls.
The Three Sisters.
Windy beaches of Kiama.
The Kiama blowhole, a major tourist attraction.
Torquay beach.
Rocks near the lighthouse.
Split Point Lighthouse.
View from the lighthouse.
Start of the Great Ocean Road.
Lookout near the town of Lorne.
Mariners Lookout over Apollo Bay.
Rainforest of Otway National Park.
At the Twelve Apostles.
Some of the Apostles.
Loch and Gorge inset.
Hidden beach at the inset.
London Bridge.
Bay of Islands near Peterborough.
Sticks Winery.
Winefields.
Chocolate delight at the Yarra Valley Chocolaterie.
Winefields of the Soumah Winery.
Food platter to go with delicous wine.
Brisbane River, with the cliffs of Kangaroo Point on the other side.
City Boardwalk.
Surfers Paradise.
Surfers Paradise boulevard.
Miami-like houses of Surfers Paradise.
Sunset over Brisbane.
The free red water taxi.
South Bank walk.
Public pool.
Brisbane CBD.
Main shopping street.
Jonge Jenever (gin).
Every Wednesday, “de Markt” is in town. It’s like food trucks, but not limited to food.
Forrest Place.
Northbridge district; the main nightlife area, lined with bars and restaurants.
An outdoor movie showing at the Institute of Contemporary Arts.
View over the CBD from Kings Park.
Vasse Felix Winery.
Wines of the Cape Mentelle Winery.
Xanadu Wines in the Margaret Valley.
Chocolate tasting in Margaret Valley.
Winefields in the Swan Valley, located about 30 minutes northeast of Perth.
Hundreds of limestone formations at The Pinnacles.
Lake Burley Griffin, with the National Carillon bell tower on Aspen Island.
At the start.
Final kilometer leads into the Melbourne Cricket Ground.
Sprint to the finish line.
Gun time: 1h29′16″, net time: 1h28′59″.
Hipster-like market in Kuranda.
An almost dried up Barron Falls, and view over the Kuranda National Park.
Palm Cove Beach.
We got a free triple upgrade on our rental car, making it way too big for just the two of us.
At the Reef platform just before heading back to Cairns.
Cairns Esplanade Lagoon.
Cradle Mountain.
Dove Lake and the Cradle Mountain.
One of many trails in the Cradle Mountain National Park.
Trail surroundings.
Cataract Gorge.
Binalong Bay.
Fantastic views despite the clouds.
Hiking trail up to the Wineglass Bay Lookout.
Wineglass Bay.
Two Tasmanian Devils at Unzoo.
Kangaroos.
Hobart Street Mall.
Salamanca Market.
Outside Salamanca Market.
Art at MONA.
Almost at the top of Mt. Wellington.
Mt. Wellington summit.
Electronics.
Sweet and sour chicken with rice, and Pad Thai, two Thai street food favorites. The Chang beer remains our favorite beer so far.
Eating on the street next to traffic.
Pang Gee fritter, a Thai desert made of coconut, taro and palm sugar with corn.
Pang Gee with chocolate.
The ferry from Angra dos Reis to Ilha Grande.
Beijinho de Coco (top): coconut truffles, and Pão de Queijos (bottom): cheese bread.
Choripán sandwich, meat empanada, and the underwhelming Quilmes beer.
Flank steak with a potato and vegetable lasagna.
Dulce de leche (boiled condensed milk) chocolate cake.
Sticky crossaints and dulce the leche spreading.
Chocolate-covered alfajore, and dulce rellena.
Steak and fries.
Helado: the Argentinian variant of frozen yoghurt. Simply delicous: we highly recommend the “El Calafate” (blueberry) flavour.
Giant avocado.
Pastel de Choclo: a pie with beef, chicken, egg, olives, and raisins, topped off with a corn puree. Surprisingly delicious.
Corn Humitas: contains a corn paste which we did not particularly like.
Egg baked in avocado, not good when eaten hot.
Coconut cake topped with meringue.
Capel Sour; similar to the ingredient used to make pisco sours.
Selection of Bolivian desserts - we recommend getting them fresh from the bakery though.
City center.
Dodging the roadblocks on the way to Copacabana.
Cusqueña beer - our favorite Peruvian beer.
A taxi we never should have taken in Lima. Picture says it all.

The near-empty plane from Lima to Guayaquil. Due to the flight being international, tickets ran very expensive (think $500+) for this one hour flight. We managed to get a good deal, avoiding a 24hr bus ride.
The main beer of Ecuador, allright tasting but nothing special.
Fioravanti: fruity carbonated softdrink with strawberry flavour, accompanied with plantain chips.
Club beer, tries to compete with Pilseners’ popularity but unsuccessfully so.
Sour mango with salt, a common snack but we felt salt was not needed.
Poker beer - popular in Bogotá (our favorite).
Between the coffee plants.
Araza fruit ice cream (very similar to passion fruit in taste) with casquitos; a jelly made from the outer part of the coffee cherry fruit (very nice sweet and sour taste).
Amazing Arabica coffee.
Choclomelos: chocolate covered marshmallows, not as good as the German version.
Colombian rum - spicy flavors and quite smooth.
Happy hour in the bar means free fancy drinks.
Pool.
Our private boat for the day.
One of many resorts on our way to Castaway Island.
Resort on Castaway Island.
Beautiful looking beach, yet not that good for swimming.
Colorful catamaran on the beach.
Enjoying a luke warm beer on the beach.
Uninhabited island of Malamala.
Extremely clear waters, yet when snorkeling we didn’t see that much sealife.
Preparation stage, about an hour before the start.
Many of the 16,000 runners eager to get started.
Smiles after the first 13km flew by.
Exhaustion. Taken around the 25km mark.
A glass of chocolate milk never tasted better.
Pandas at the Beijing Zoo. They didn’t look entirely happy.
The sun was out during our visit, making for a pleasant (and busy) hike.
Sections of the Great Wall at Badaling.
Steamed vegetable and pork dumplings with a garlic-vinegar soy sauce.
The Birds Nest, known from the recent Olympic Games.
The butt (we think) of a duck (we think).
Egg tart, popular in both Hong Kong and China. This desert has a creamy semi-sweet filling.
The plane for our first leg: Beijing to Abu Dhabi.
Guava paste and white cheese stacked on top. An acquired taste.
Assortment of deserts including coconut, lemon, apple-pecan, passion fruit, and chocolate sprinkle cake.
Mountain Dew for Brazilians, has a cherry flavour.
Fried cassava flour (top) and black bean stew with different kinds of beef and sausage.
Dish made with tripe. Yikes.
Delicious strogonoff sauce.
Fried snacks stuffed with chicken and creamy cheese.
Brigadeiro: chocolate truffle made with condensed milk, covered in chocolate sprinkles. Not as good as the Dutch ones.
Cobblestone streets of Paraty.
Selection of beers. Our favorite is Brahma, although Skol, Itaipava, Antarctica, and Bohemian are popular as well.
Paraty beach.
Açaí, a superfood berry topped with bananas and granola. Healthy and delicious.
The bus that brought us from Paraty to the ferry to Ilha Grande.
At the finish line of the Death Road.
View during our hike to Lopes Mendes.
Another beach on the way to Lopes Mendes.
Boats cannot go here as the water is very shallow.
Water taxi to transport people between beaches.
Aqueduct supplying the town with fresh water.

Caipirinha, Brazil’s national cocktail. Tastes like tequila with lime. If you dont like Cachaça, Vodka as a replacement works too. In front: fried yuca sticks, tasted like fries. Very filling and surprisingly good.
Brazilian cream cheese.
Hiking trail to the Parrot Peak.
Panoramic views from the peak.
When we were about to descent, a misty cloud rolled in.
Church in the center of Abraão. The Parrot Peak can be seen in the background.
Leaving Ilha Grande.
Christ the Redeemer.
Heart-shaped lake.
The favela featured in the movie Fast & Furious.
Lapa steps.
Cathedral.
Inside the cathedral.
Carioca Aqueduct.
Morro da Urca.
View of Copacabana.
Cable car transporting people up Sugarloaf Mountain in Rio de Janeiro.
Antarctica and Bohemia beer.
Ipanema.
The best thing about Rio’s beaches: a cold coconut.
The shuttle bus to the Brazilian side of the falls.
Greedy coati going for another cookie.
The only close-up on the Brazilian side. Be prepared to get wet.
Bus connecting the Puerto Iguazú with the Argentinian side of the Iguazú Falls.
Train for transportation within the Iguazú Falls park.
Argentinian blue cheese.
School of Law.
In the Boca neighborhood.
Colorfol streets in the Boca neighborhood.
Alfajor: a dulce de leche filled cookie.
Stadium of Boca Juniors.
Riverfront.
Obelisco de Buenos Aires monument.
Tango lessons.
Another meat-filled empanada.
Delicious wine, served at the tango show.
Steak and assorted vegetables.
Tango show.
Dulce de leche flan.
Picturesque streets of the old town.
Lighthouse.
Old city wall.
Main church.
Colonia has an unusual amount of vintage cars.
Lomito sandwich.
Ferry from Buenos Aires to Colonia, Uruguay.
Yerba mate.
Choripán with delicious chimichurri sauce.
Chimichurri.
Main square in Buenos Aires.
Cathedral.
Submarino: a chocolate bar dipped in hot milk.
Bus to El Chaltén.
Views over the valley.
The Fitz Roy peak starts to reveal itself.
Lush valley view. The winds were very fierce here.
Almost at the viewpoint.
Laguna Capri, providing water safe to drink.
On the Fitz Roy Viewpoint.
Chicago-style pizza. Very typical in Patagonia.
A typical town in Patagonia: small, and surrounded by nothingness.
The fruity local beer in El Calafate.
Side view of the glacier and Lago Argentino.
Front view.
Entrance to the Perito Moreno Glacier Park.
Bus to the Perito Moreno Glacier, also departing from El Calafate.
On our way to Torres del Paine.
Tour bus in Torres del Paine, not recommended as the unsealed windows let a lot of dust in due to the gravel roads.
Lago Sarmiento.
Guanacos (lama relatives).
Rhea.
Laguna Amarga.
Wild blueberries from Torres del Paine.
Lago Nordenskjöld.
Lago Pehoe.
Glacier Lake, with small floating icebergs.
Charming downtown park in Puerto Natales.
Lago Sofía.
Completo: a hotdog with avocado, chopped tomaties, and a ridiculous amount of mayo.
The Chileans like to put mayo on everything - hence the supermarkets offer a huge selection.
Juice box wine.
Manjar, the Chilean desert version of dulce de leche.
Austral beer; not much taste to it. Try the Argentinian Patagonia beer instead.
Cocada: crunchy cookie with soft coconut inside.
Bus from Puerto Natales to Ushuaia (and back).
Local beer in Ushuaia with very nice honey taste.
Boat showing us around the Beagle Channel.
Bird Island filled with cormorands.
Sea lions.
Lighthouse at the end of the world.
Penguin colony on Isla Martillo.
Southernmost city of the world.
Gigantic spider crab in Ushuaia. We did not try this one.
Aji sauce, a garlic-based sauce good on bread and meat.

Patagonian lamb; this particular one was not very well prepared as it wasn’t tender enough. Try to look for a restaurant that displays the lamb as it is slowly cooked and may offer a more tender meat.
Punta Arenas downtown - quite a nice area.
Six days worth of shopping.
Chocolate-puff filled with Portuguese cream. Sweet, but good.
Anakena Beach.
Statues in front of the beach.
Ovahe Beach.
Fallen statue at Ahu Te Pito Kura.
Rental car on Easter Island.
Crater Lake of Rano Kau, littered with statues.
Rano Kau is the place where most of the statues were created.
Rano Kau.
Never finished statue still in rock.
Fifteen in a row at Ahu Tongariki.
Ahu Akivi.
Watch out for wild horses and cows.
Ahu Tahai.
Another surreal crater lake (Rano Raraku).
Ancient settlement of Orongo.
One of many performances during the Tapati Festival.
Fried plantains with tartar sauce.
Delicious local fresh fish.
Pineapple juice.
Baby pineapples.
Town of Hanga Roa.
Mahina pale ale; refreshing and flavorful.
Porter version of the Mahina beer, heavy and very bitter.
Cold and clear waters, very refreshing.
Scooter rental on Easter Island. Uncommonly, we found renting a simple scooter required a motorbike license in addition to car license.
Traditional parade through town to close the festivities.
Tropical juice popular among the islanders.
Our home for a week. Basic, and very hot, but quite the experience.
2010 Valdivieso Merlot with a very strong tabacco aftertaste.
Terremoto (earthquake): wine, fernet, and pineapple ice cream. Gets you drunk quickly, hence the name.
Seafood empanada with spicy aji sauce.
Chacarero Chileno: avocado sandwich with a thinly-sliced steak.
Mote con Huesillos; a sweet sugary drink with peach flavor and corn at the bottom. Not our favorite.
Cable car in Santiago.
Bus from Santiago to Mendoza.
The first winery of the day at Familia di Tommaso.
Wine storage.
Underground barrel storage, as temperatures here are much cooler.
Second wine-tasting at Mevi.
Wine fields.
Exploring the area by bike is by far the most flexible and enjoyable.
Grapes, winefields, and the Andes mountains.
Third wine tasting at Viña El Cérno.
Olive oil tasting.
Jam tasting.
Liquor and chocolate tasting.
Selection of four local wines at La Botella.
Charming town of San Pedro de Atacama.
Excellent, yet expensive, taxi service found in major cities in Chile.
Cavernas de Sal - salt caves.
Roads of Valle de la Luna.
Tres Marías rocks, and the unearthly landscape.
Sand dunes.
View over the Moon Valley, used by NASA to test their Mars Landers.
On the Piedra del Coyote lookout point.
View over the Small Canyon.
Our jeep in San Pedro got stuck on a sandy ridge. We continued on foot.
Sunset over Valle de la Muerte.
Tour bus bringing us to Geyser del Tatio.
Géiser del Tatio has about 80 geysers.
Geyser pool - we went in, but it wasn’t as warm or nice (very rocky) as we thought.
View over the geysers.
View over the Andes Mountains.
A stick of delicious llama meat.
Goat-cheese filled empanada.
Flamingos.
Loading up our jeep at the Chilean-Bolivian border.
Laguna Verde.
Our home for three days during the Salar de Uyuni tour.
Salvador Dalí Desert.
Sol de Mañana.
Laguna Colorada.
Laguna Colorada.
The basic dorm.
Our hostel in Huayliajara.
Laguna Colorada.
Árbol de Piedra.
Árbol de Piedra.
Colorful rock formations around the Cerro Bayo vulcano.
A vizcacha.
Driving through the Cerros del Inca valley.
Pale-yellow Laguna Honda.
Laguna Honda.
A fox at Laguna Chiar Kkota.
Laguna Chiar Kkota.
The near-black lake of Turquiri.
Faces in the rock.
Condor-shaped rock in Vallede las Rocas.
Vallede las Rocas.
Quinoa-fields on our way to Alota.
Private room.
Potato soup.
The hostel in Alota.
Train cemetery.
On our way to the wet section of Salar de Uyuni.
The perfect mirror.
Surreal, and almost impossible to see where the horizon ends.
The three jeeps of Cordillera Traveller on the salt flats.
Dry flats.
Terrible bus from Uyuni to La Paz. Not a smooth ride, and on top the bus let in local people who slept under the seats.
The hilly streets in the historic center.
Local market.
View of the historic center, the Saint Francisco Church, and many houses on the hill.
Plaza Mayor, and many houses up the hill.
Saint Francisco Church.
Mercado Lanza.
Av. Montes, the main street leading into the city.
Unloading the bikes.
First test ride to try out the brakes.
Preparing our top-notch bikes.
The start of the Death Road.
The ride descended from 4,850m to 1,500m: cloudy at the top, warm and sunny at the bottom.
Traffic on Yungas Road drives on the left, which is deemed safer as the driver is on the side of the ravine, and can see its wheels from the window.
One of the widest sections.
Dramatic drops of up to 600 meters.
Bus carrying all the bikes on the Death Road.
A technical stop during our descent as our guides explained the next section coming up.
Valley near the town of Coroico.
Llajua: Bolivian spicy sauce made from peppers and tomatoes.
The drive back to La Paz turned out to be the most scary part of the day.
Arrival by tiny plane.
Tiniest plane ever made for a bumpy ride from La Paz to Rurrenabaque.
Outside Rurrenabaque, the only way to get around is by boat.
After three hours on the Beni river, we arrived at our lodge.
Map of trails in the national park.
The lodge.
Green papaya salad.
Chicken with fries, a very common combination in Bolivia
Papaya juice.
A delicious dessert of banana with chocolate sauce.
Walking trail surrounded by trees, insects, and unknown sounds.
Açaí tree.
Print of a guinea pig.
Lookout point.
Another lookout point.
Soup with fries, surprisingly good.
Quinoa with grilled catfish.
Banana-flour desert - not that sweet.
Nightwalk in the Amazon.
The nicest (but probably also poisonous) thing we saw: a yellow frog.
Walking path to our lodge.
Inside the lodge, away from the mosquitos.
Leafs of the Galipea Longiflora tree have antiparasitic properties.
Piperaceae leafs, useful to treat kidney problems, fever, and coughing.
Seed containing oil used to prevent hair loss.
Wild papaya tree.
Copaibo tree. The oil is extracted by making a hole in the tree, and is used to heal wounds.
Chuchuhuasi tree from which the bark is used as pain reliever.
The vines of these trees contain small amounts of water in case of emergency.
Nature’s cotton swabs.
Green spider.
Local transport in Rurrenabaque and the Amazon.
Muddy river full of piranhas.
Piranha fishing. We caught one, unfortunately it was able to escape the line before pulled ashore.
Buckwheat with fried meat and a Russian-style beet salad.
Bolivian chocolates.
A delicious lemon pie.
Bus from La Paz to Copacabana. At the border with Peru, we had to switch to a different bus.
Crossing the canal.
Main street of Copacabana, a typical tourist town.
We didn’t try this one: fries covered with hot dogs, egg, caramelized onions, ketchup, mayonnaise, and mustard.
The flavorful Paceña beer.
Lake Titicaca from Isla del Sol.
View of Isla de la Luna (Moon Island) from Isla del Sol (Sun Island).
Colorful houses of Yumani town.
Entrance to Yumani.
The harbor of Yumani.
The bus from the Peruvian border to Cusco. Way more comfortable than its Bolivian counterpart.
Yuca Croquettes: yucca tuber with zucchini, pepper, cheese, and chili sauce with avocado makes for a filling appetizer.
Guacamole Tequenos, a wantan dough with cheese and avocado, lemon, and chili sauce dip was a delicious appetizer.
Alpaca Medallion in a Rosemary Sauce with mashed potatoes - the flavorful lean meat was delicious, however the rather sweet mashed potatoes made for a strange accompanying dish.
Plaza de Armas in Cusco.
Pisco sour, the national drink made with traditional sour pisco and egg whites did not disappoint.
Peru offers a great variety of fresh juices, like this pineapple juice.
Pollo A La Brasa sandwich and Lomo Saltado (thinly sliced beef saluted with vegetables) with creamy quinoa risotto.
The old city gate.
Inca Kola, a super sweet candy tasting soda which was not our favorite although very popular among locals and other tourists.
Hearty potato soup with gigantic corn and cheese appetizer.
Lucuma ice cream: not too sweet with a pumpkin texture did not compete with Argentinas cheap and yummy helados.
Church.
Quinoa pound cake - quite delicious and filling.
Cheap and delicious vegetarian place for lunch offering anything from veggie burgers to pizzas.
Bus from Cusco to the train to Machu Picchu.
The train to Machu Picchu - slow, but very scenic. Comes with a hefty price tag of $150 pp.
Traditional Peruvian butter cookie.
The town of Machu Picchu.
Surroundings while ascending to Machu Picchu.
The first view.
On the Inca Bridge trail.
The Inca Bridge, a secret entrance into the city.
The trail.
Ruins of Machu Picchu.
Stair-like hill.
Just outside Plaza Mayor: a large police presence, and Lima suburbs on the hill.
Shopping street just outside of Plaza Mayor.
The main square in downtown Lima.
Government Palace.
Lima cathedral.
Pilsen, a local beer in Lima, yet not as good as cusqueña.

Rocoto relleno: spicy hot pepper filled with minced meat and topped with cheese. We did not particularly dislike this dish, but we also did not like it as it was loaded with meat. The potato-cheese lasagna on the other hand was quite delicious.
The fancy buildings of the Miraflores neighborhood.
Seaside shopping mall of Larcomar.
Coastline of Lima, unfortunately not swimmable due to the rocks.
Baked gigantic corn made for a delicious alternative snack, as long as it is served warm.
Ceviche - bite size pieces of fresh fish perfectly “cooked” in lime sauce.
Pelicans, sea lions, and blue-footed booby in the harbor in Puerto Ayora.
Turtles at the Charles Darwin Research Station.
Tortuga Beach.
Tortuga Bay with incoming thunderstorm.
Water taxi on the Galápagos.
On the way to Las Grietas one passes Playa los Alemanes.
Las Salinas: a red salt lagoon, just before arriving at Las Grietas.
Las Grietas - a crevasse with mix of rain and sea water.
Boat for the tour to North Seymour.
Swallow-tail gull with kid.
Blue-footed booby.
Young magnificent frigate bird.
Frigate birds.
Land iguana.
Young sea lion.
Corn empanadas with meat filling.
Two Galápagos sharks.
Rice with fish, a variant on the popular Arroz con Camarones.
Sweet naranjilla juice.
Las Bachas beach, with a marine iguana.
On the way back to the harbor.
Mora juice, a red berry which taste like a mixture of raspberries and blackberries.
Venezuela Street, with a great view of the basilica.
Plaza Grande.
Palacio de Carondelet.
Ecuadorian candy, deepfried with extra sugar. Not our favorite.
La Virgen de Quito.
Square in the La Ronda neighborhood.
Colorful streets in La Ronda, most alive at night.
Espumilla: an whipped-like dessert with a distinctive guava flavour.
Llapingachos: potato patties mixed with cheese, served with a fried egg on top and avocado and meat on the side.
Fanesca: a heavy soup served only around Easter.
Basilica del Voto Nacional.
Palomino Flores, the central park in Baños.
Cuy: guinea pig. Taste like chicken, but does not have a lot of meat.
The process of making melcocha, a very sweet local toffee, dangerous for your teeth.
The end product.
Basílica Virgen de Agua Santa.
Mountains around the town.
On the swing (1).
On the swing (2).
Twisting and turning on the swing.
Casa del Arbol: the swing at the end of the world.
The “view” from the swing.
Surroundings of Casa del Arbol. The greenhouses on the hillsides are for tomato harvesting.
Bus bringing us to the swing in Baños. Very plain, but also only 1$.
Bus from Quito to Baños - for $3.50 this was a bargain, and on top they showed a (Spanish) movie too!
Salchipapas: fries topped with a special sauce made from tomato purée, homemade mayo, aji, and onions. Very yummy but a bit spicy.
Pollo a la Parrilla: tender and delicious grilled chicken from the Dulche Carbón restaurant.
La Mitad del Mundo monument.
At the monument.
0°0′0″ degrees.
North and south, as seen from the monument.
Ajiaco: a potato-based soup with corn and capers, topped with sour cream.

Bandeja Paisa: a heavy plate consisting of chorizo sausages, grilled steak, fried pork rind, rice, and beans. Topped with a fried egg, avocado, and sweet banana chips. It’s considered the national dish of Colombia. We found one was plenty for two people to share, however it was a bit too heavy for us.
Hot chocolate (non-sweetened) with cheese - the cheese did not alter the taste of the hot chocolate drastically, however it was an interesting taste.
Maracuya coconut cocada: super sweet but the sour passion fruit taste balanced the sugar and coconut very well.
Aguardiente: anise liquor that is super cheap and popular in Colombia (we didn’t like it because of the strong anise taste as it resembled the green fairy quite a bit).
Plaza del Chorro de Quevedo in the La Candelaria neighborhood.
Colorful streets of La Candelaria.
Street art.
Street leading to Plaza de Bolivar.
Iglesia de Candelaria (church), and Museo de Botero on the right.
(Fat) Mona Lisa by Fernando Botero.
Mapa de Colombia by Fernand Léger.
Obleas: thin wafer with condensed milk in the middle.
Capitolio Nacional on the main plaza.
Catedral Primada de Colombia.
Arepa cornmeal pancake with gooey cheese in the middle (yummy, the corn version not so yummy).
High-end fashion street in Zona T.
Empty streets due to Easter festivities elsewhere.
Aguilar beer - we preferred the regular one instead of the light version.
French fries sprinkled with paprika, delicious.
Delicious ice cream from Crepes & Waffles, close in quality and price to Argentinian ice cream.
Foodtrucks.
Metro buses in Bogotá, although Lima and Quito had the same set-up: separate lanes and double buses driving like crazy. In the background Monumento los Heroés.
Costena - a beer we found in Pereira - not good.
Jeep dropping people off at the Cocora Valley. The jeep is tiny yet carrying 10+ people was no exception.
Lush green Cocora Valley.
Wax palms, the symbol of Colombia.
Hiking trail.
Hill littered with wax palms.
The valley covered in clouds.
Center of Salento.
Mirador Alto de la Cruz in Salento.
Corn Arepa with cheese.
Canelazo, a hot cinnamon drink with rum - yum!
Fried trout with plantain chip - tasteless and not good for you, we would recommend spending a little extra for the grilled version.
Bus from Pereira to Salento, plain and cheap (2.50$).
Coffee beans.
Coffee fields of Don Manolo.
Drying beans.
Ice cream made with the peel of the coffee bean.
5kg of coffee beans.
Traditional coffee pickers.
Plaza de Bolívar in Pereira.
One of many market streets.
Cordilleras Artisan beer - quite tasteful compared to most Colombian beers.
The Clock Tower is the main entrance gate into the city.
Square full of restaurants right next to the Clock Tower.
San Pedro Claver church.
Plaza de Santa Teresa.
One of many small squares in the city.
Parque de Bolívar.
High-rise buildings of Bocagrande.
Castillo San Felipe de Barajas.
Statue of India Catalina, an important figure in the Spanish conquest of Colombia.
Club Colombia, the most popular beer in Colombia, but not our favorite.
Playa Blanca: the best beach of Cartagena, which is actually located about one hour south.
Local vendors took over the waterfront, but still the beach was enjoyable.

Grilled bass with patroness (green plantains made into thick pancakes) with Arroz con Coco (rice cooked in coconut milk, sugar, and raisins). We were quite disappointed with the rice as the raisins overpowered the dish. The fish, on the other hand, was very well prepared.
Balcony-lined streets of the historic center.
Coconut and lime lemonade - we did not like the mix of the two flavors.
Water in a bag? How does that work?
The pool part of the Casa Dann Carlton spa, which turned out to be quite enjoyable.
Taking a break from backpacking.
Ron Viejo de Caldas - local spicy Colombian rum.
Our plane from Bogotá to Fort Lauderdale.
Scenic view of the Multnomah Falls.
Views from Portland ’s Mount Hood.
Food trucks.
Waterfront.
It was way too cold, but an hour outside Portland this is a popular weekend destination (in the summer, we guess).
Crossing from Oregon into Washington state at Point Ellice.
False Creek leading into Vancouver.
Harbors around Granville Island.
Popular waterfront for a walk, run, or bike-ride.
Sunset from the Vancouver Tower.
Bridge from beautiful and large Stanley Park.
Suspension bridge turned into a tourist attraction.
Vancouver has a Dutch Shopping Center filled with delicious Dutch treats.
Packing chaos.
Everything we will need for the next seven months. The carry-on will be left in Amsterdam.
Kroket, from the vending machine.
One of Mark’s favorite walks: along the colorful apartment buildings and the Ringvaart river.
De Kromme Mijdrecht river, just before merging into the Amstel river.
Licorice.
Flags from representing countries just outside the Olympic Stadium.
The boat from Mark’s parents. All ready for winter.
Survival Kit.
Chocolate sprinkles.
Vlaflip. A mix of vanilla pudding and yoghurt.
Leverworst. For on your sandwich.
Erwtensoep.
Herta’s favorite treeline, located behind Mark’s house, during sunset.
View on the Veluwemeer from the hotel in Putten.
Fishing boat and mill “de Hoop”.
Sadly the umbrelas were of little help.
Apple Pie.

Eating like the locals.

Fries with mayonaise. We stole it from Belgium.

Poffertjes.

Approaching Wat Arun by ferry.
After climbing a set of very, very steep stairs.

Queen Sirikit Botanic Garden.
Flower Market.
Narrow streets of the flower market.
Taxi boat station.
Bangkoks’ flag boats connecting the waterfront.
Suan Lumphini.
Dinner served in the Transport Co bus to Chiang Mai.
Overnight bus from Bangkok to Chiang Mai.
A songthaew.
Tuk-tuk, useful for very short distance trips only as it is not the safest.
Streets decorated with lanterns because of the festival.
Doi Suthep.
It was a rainy day, yet temperatures still in the high 20s.
View over Chiang Mai.
Stairs from and to Doi Suthep.
Coconut-milk pancake sprinkled with sugar, and quail eggs with maggi made for a great snack.
Lantern parade.
Lantern parade.
Lanterns outside of Tha Phae Gate.
Chiang Mai noodle soup with beef.
Sticky rice cookie.
Release of a lantern.
Wat Chedi Luang.
Wat Chedi Luang.
Tha Phae Gate into Chiang Mai.
Thai overnight train, heading to Krabi.
Sleeper compartments, lower bunkbeds are slightly bigger. Bumpy ride still.
Beach of Ao Nang, about 20 minutes by taxi from Krabi.
The craziness at James Bond Island. Still a great place to visit.
Driver of the longtail boats transporting tourists to the islands.
Several travel agencies also use longtailboats for conducting tours.
Floating village of Ko Pan Yi, mainly restaurants here to feed the tourists passing by.
Yummy pineapple cookie.
Fried egg with spicy seafood.
Coconut juice. As fresh as it gets.
Sunset at Koh Lanta.
Ko Chueak.
Longtailboat, used for transporting tourists to the different beaches around Krabi.
Hidden beach - only accessible by swimming through the Emerald Cave.
Private beach of Koh Ngai.
Sunset at Koh Lanta, two days later.
We were lucky to catch a series of festivals while in Krabi, meaning great food and shows to enjoy.
Cave at Khao Nang, just 10 minutes away from Ao Nang beach by boat.
Tourists, tourists, tourists at Railey Beach.
Swimming with a view.
Unfortunately, all the boats took away much of the scenery.
Railay East Beach. The picture looks nice, but the beach looked and smelled disgusting.
Hairy tree in George Town.
Malaysian ferry connecting Penang Island to the mainland. Simple and cheap (1$).
Malaysian sleeper train. More spacious than its Thai counterpart.
Sleeper compartments.
Street food at Jalan Alor.
One of the many versions of nasi prepared on the Malaysian street.
A few hours later, Jalan Alor lights up.
Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, and Singapore all have regular subways, but the monorail is unique to Kuala Lumpur.
Masjid Jamek mosque.
Central Market.
Sultan Abdul Samad Building.
Independence Square.
Batu Caves.
Petronas Twin Towers.
Durian puff. Anything made with durian is definitely an acquired taste, it is extremely smelly.
Dragon fruit; does not really taste like anything, but it is very healthy.
Excited for our next adventure: Singapore.
Daytime train from Kuala Lumpur to Singapore: very spacious and comfortable seats.
Marina Bay Sands first appearance, while walking towards the bay area.
The Helix bridge, Marina Bay Sands, and Art Museum.
Floating Stadium.
Business district.
On top of Marina Bay Sands.
The infinity pool, unfortunately only accessible for hotel guests.
Laska - delicious tart and spicy noodle soup. On the right: stir-fried fruit and chicken sprinkled with peanuts.
At night, the bay area turns into a light show.
Therefore, not everyone likes Durians.
Christmas in the sea aquarium.
Not everyone was happy to see us.
The southernmost point of continental Asia. Ships everywhere.
Inbound rain storm.
The only way to get a clear picture of this is to wait for the tropical rain to fall.
Old town.
Murtabak, a filling flaky dough stuffed with chicken and vegetables.
Green tea custard bun.
Egg custard bun.
Delicious Pad Thai - go to the “Pad Thai Pratu Phi” restaurant. It is a bit more pricy, but definitely worth it. Order some of their freshly squeezed orange juice while you’re there as well.
Third-class Thai train without luxuries like A/C. We only used this for a short 40-minute transfer to the airport.
Angkor Wat.
Angkor Wat.
Sunrise makes for a beautiful color.
Bayon temples.
Faces all around the temple.
Tree-covered temples of Ta Prohm.
Ta Prohm.
Caramel rice cookie. Typical Cambodian snack.
Oil drenched pancake with stir-fried noodles. Not much taste to it.
Khmer deserts consist of diluted condensed milk mixed with ice and anything pumpkin to taro, but not too sweet.
Crabs.
Snails sauteed in a sweet chilly paste sauce.
Crickets. A delicacy in Cambodia.
Longan fruit. Not the most sweet, tasty, or good looking fruit.
The best bus in Cambodia: Giant Ibis. We used it twice, from Siem Reap to Phnom Penh and onwards to Ho Chi Minh City.
The roads, on the other hand, were terrible.
Decorations around many of the mass graves in Choeung Ek.
The Killing Fields.
Prison. For many prisoners, the Killing Fields at Choeung Ek would be their final destination.
Vietnamese Pho with a well-balanced broth.
Waterfront of Ho Chi Minh City.
Saigon Notre-Dame Basilica cathedral originating from the French occupation.
The local market.
Bami sandwich, contains anything from chicken to eggs. Found on any street corner, just look for long lines and avoid the coriander.
Coconut candy in the making.
Waterways of the Mekong Delta.
Motorbikes. Motorbikes. Motorbikes.
Sleeper bus on our daytime (!) journey to Mũi Né.
Very strange layout, but reasonable comfortable as long as you’re not too tall.
There’s nothing a bit of duck tape and cardboard can’t fix.
Red Sand Dunes in Mũi Né.
Fishing village of Mũi Né.
“American” jeep transporting us to the Sand Dunes of Mũi Né.
White Sand Dunes.
Daytime bus back to Ho Chi Minh City. Very small seats, and the driver liked to take shortcuts. Not as good as it sounds.
Củ Chi tunnels from the Vietnam War.
Tapioca sweet potato with a peanut sauce. Common food for the Vietnamese during the war.
Active train tracks through a narrow street.
Bun Cha: grilled meat, noodles, topped with peanuts.
Old Hanoi city wall.
Creamy egg coffee is a Hanoi favorite, although strong Vietnamese black coffee with condensed milk is also common.
Hoàn Kiếm Lake in the center of Hanoi.
Top deck.
Cruising the bays.
Vung Vieng fishing village.
Kayaking through the village.
Halong Bay junk of Paloma Cruise.
Top deck during sunset.
You don’t pick - but get all of these.
With live cooking. Or setting the boat on fire, not sure.
Attempting to create a fresh spring roll from its ingredients: lettuce, carrots, prawn, wrapped in rice paper.
Our room.
Traditional Vietnamese breakfast.
The bay with all the other junks, before entering the cave.
Inside the Hang Sửng Sốt cave.
Sapa Express connecting Hanoi and Sa Pá. Very smooth journey thanks to the new highway.
Facilities were lacking though. This is the restroom stop.
The fruity Lao Cai beer.
Suspension bridge over the Muong Hoa stream.
Showing the Black H’mong tribe how it’s done.
Muddy trails of the valley.
One of two Rattan Bridges in the area - hidden by the tree.
Sa Pá offered a vast variety of hot wines, combined with anything from cinnamon to chilis.
Star Ferry connecting Hong Kong with the Kowloon district. Great views from the water for only 0.40$.
Hong Kong skyline from the Star Ferry.
Bruce Lee statue on the Avenue of Stars.
World’s longest covered escalators.
Double-decker bus (left) and tram (right). Tram is the cheapest (0.40$ flat rate), but also very slow.
Venetian Macau.
The Galaxy casino.
Macau Taipa Ferry Terminal.
Old Portuguese remains.
High-speed TurboJET ferry connecting Hong Kong to Macau. Not that pleasant, even during calm sees it can get bumpy.
Cold and windy, awaiting nighttime.
Victoria Gap: Hong Kong at nighttime.
The quickest way down: take the old tram.
People’s Square in the Huangpu district.
Lujiazui skyline from The Bund.
The Bund Sightseeing Tunnel.
Lujiazui financial district.
Oriental Pearl Tower.
Pringles on a stick, and boiled quail eggs.
The traditional Chinese town of Qibao.
Tanghulu: strawberries with a sugar coating, a very popular Chinese treat.
Awaiting the ERA Acrobats.
Greasy yet delicious Chow Mein noodles.
Seats are comfortable and spacious, journey is very smooth.
Bullet train from Shanghai to Beijing - only took five hours.
Entrance to the Forbidden City.
Temperatures hovered around freezing, but the windchill made it worse.
After passing a series of gates, one arrives at the gardens of the Forbidden City.
It is hard to understand just how big the Forbidden City is, the birds eye view from the park gives you a good impression.
The famous square just south of the Forbidden City.
